title.narrative: Umbrella Facility for Gender Equality (UFGE) 2015-2023 TF71893; TF072809

description.narrative:
Jämställdhetsfonden (UFGE) är en global fond, som ligger inom ramen för Världsbanken och International Finance Coperation (IFC) verksamhet. Fonden syftar till att stärka kunskapen, medvetenheten och kapaciteten för ett mer medvetet utvecklande av jämställdhetsområdet. Målet är fylla de kunskapsluckor som idag råder inom jämställdhetsagendan och som fortfarande existerar. Fondens syfte är att sprida den globala kunskapen, och främja evidens baserat beslutsfattande. UFGE grundades för en inledande period på fem år (2012-2017) och är i linje med Världsbanks gruppens strategi för jämställdhet. För närvarande stöder UFGE mer än 60 projekt i mer än 40 länder. Den sammanfattande bedömningen är att UFGE, och det tematiska arbetet med att främja jämställdhet på ett övergripande och holistiskt sätt, är relevant och passar väl in inom ramen för Strategin för mänskliga rättigheter och demokratisering 2014-2017. UFGE och Världsbanken samt IFC har de system på plats för att kunna säkerställa intern styrning och kontroll. Målen som insatsen direkt ska bidra till är två delmål i strategin och insatsen ligger väl i linje med PGU. UFGE uppfyller system kraven för att ingå ett samarbete och avtal med Sida. Det bedöms därför att insatsen ska formaliseras genom avtal.
UFGE är strategisk för Sida ur flera perspektiv. Först, WB är en viktig aktör inom sektorn för jämställdhet. Världsbanken är en aktör som både regeringar och andra myndigheter lyssnar till. För det andra har arbetet med jämställdhet inom WB förbättrats de senaste åren och blivit betydligt bättre på att positionera jämställdhet som en central fråga inom WB aktiviteter och sektorer. Sverige och Sida har varit en av de drivande krafterna bakom reformen av jämställdhetdagordningen inom Världsbanken. För det tredje; har UFGE en mycket viktig roll att spela gällande kunskapshantering (data och insamling av information). Det finns en mycket stor informationsklyfta inom området jämställdhet och evidensbaserade data och information är ofta bristfällig. Detta är centralt för jämställdhetsagenda och en av de viktiga målen för UFGE. Slutligen har Världsbanken ett mervärde i dess sammankallande makt på land- och regionalnivå och i förhållande till regeringar och myndigheter.

The Umbrella Facility for Gender Equality (UFGE) is a global fund, which lies within the framework of the World Bank (WB) and the International Finance Cooperation (IFC). The purpose of the fund is to strengthen the knowledge, awareness and capacity for a more conscious development of gender equality. The goal is to fill the knowledge gaps in the current gender agenda, that still exists. The fund's purpose is to spread global awareness, and promote evidence-based decision-making. UFGE was established for an initial period of five years (2012-2017) and is in line with the WBs strategy for gender equality. UFGE currently supports more than 60 projects in more than 40 countries. The summary assessment is that UFGE, and the thematic work to promote gender equality in a comprehensive and holistic manner, are relevant and fit well within the framework of the strategy for human rights and democratisation in 2014-2017. UFGE and the World Bank and the IFC have the systems in place to ensure internal control. The UFGE contributes to two specific sub goals of the strategy for human rights and democratisation in 2014-2017 and the contribution is also assessed to be in line with the PGD . UFGE meets the system requirements for the entering into an agreement with Sida. It is considered therefore that the UFGE should be formalised through an agreement.
The UFGE intervention is strategic for Sida from several perspectives: First, the WB is an important actor in the sector of gender equality. An actor that both governments and other authorities listen to. Second, the work of gender equality within the WB has improved in recent years and become significantly better in placing gender as a central issue within the WB activities and sectors. Sweden and Sida have been one of the driven forces behind the reform of the gender agenda within the WB. Third, the UFGE has a very important role to play in the area of knowledge management (data and information gathering). There is a very big information gap within the area of gender and evidence based data and information is scarce. This is central to the gender equality agenda and one of the key aims of the UFGE. Finally, the WB has a substantive value added in its convening power on country and regional level and in relation to governments and authorities.

The overall objective of the UFGE is to strengthen awareness, knowledge, and capacity for gender-informed policy making and programmes. It is the only World Bank Group (WBG) instrument that systematically and deliberately aims to close the gap between males and females by providing WBG teams, International Financial Institutions (IFIs), and other development partners with evidence-based solutions to demonstrate how to more effectively close such a gap as part of country and sector approaches to reduce poverty.

description.narrative:
Examples of results from FY2019: To increase effective implementation of the World Bank Groups Gender Strategy (2016-2023), the UFGE supports the development of knowledge to close gender gaps inthe pillars of the Gender Strategy: Improving Human Endowments; More and Better Jobs; Ownership and Access to Finance; and Voice and Agency. Activities and achievements are presented along these pillars, where significant results were reported.The report provides several examples of results, that emerged in FY19, of how UFGE's work has influenced policy dialogue and has advanced programmatic interventions under these pillars.
Improving Human Endowments UFGE has supported pilots and evaluations to address remaining what they call "sticky first generation issues", such as teen pregnancy and maternal mortality, especially in the poorest countries, and second-generation issues, such as improving educational outcomes for under performing boys, school-to-work transitions for young women, and challenging gender biases in fields of study all of which can impact womens occupational choices. One example on health is from the Latin America and Caribbean region, where knowledge on behavioural change is now informing government approaches to reproductive and maternal health services. With a grant awarded in FY17, the World Banks Health, Nutrition & Population Global Practice and the Mind, Behaviour and Development (eMBeD) team diagnosed demand constraints to health services, and howto overcome them, which is key to address high rates of maternal and neo-natal mortality in several of the regions countries. In Haiti, a diagnostic found that in addition to structural barriers and the inadequate quality of care services, behavioural biases and perceptions deter pregnant women from seeking medical care because they expect to be received poorly at clinics and hospitals. In FY19, as a result of the findings, the Ministry of Public Health and Population is developing a policy to better integrate traditional birth attendants in the healthcare system and develop training and support to enhance safety of the deliveries they assist as part of a new health project.
Removing Constraints for More and Better Jobs UFGE states that closing employment and income gaps requires a comprehensive multi-sector approach. Approaches currently being tested include providing safe and affordable transport, care services both for children and the elderly, making workplaces safe and respectful,reducing occupational sex-segregation, and changing social norms related to male and female employment. Activities include financing to develop public as well as private sector solutions. UFGE is currently supporting research on cost-effective and evidence-based solutions for governments and firms to provide care services, to promote female labor force participation and improve recruitment, retention, and worker productivity. One example is from Southeast Asia, were the IFC is providing actionable, quality research which in FY19 persuaded the Shwe Taung Group in Yangon, Myanmar to open two additional childcare centers in their facilities. The IFCs #Get2Equal project, launched in FY16,works directly with the private sector to implement innovative solutions to increase quality employment and business leadership opportunities for women. As part of these engagements, eight businesses in Myanmar have achieved EDGE certification - the leading global standard for gender equality.
UFGE grants also finance experimentation, impact evaluation, and policy dialog on closing entrepreneurship gaps. The FY19 report, Profiting from Parity: Unlocking the Potential of Womens Businesses in Africa, uncovers how social norms, networks and household decision contribute to business performance. The report urges action to close Africas gender gaps in business performance, drawing on new, high-quality, household and firm-level data from several Sub-Saharan African countries. The report proposes several ways to encourage women to become entrepreneurs, including supporting women with secure savings mechanisms; implementing training programs that encourage an entrepreneurial mindset; and providing apprenticeships and role models to encourage women to cross over into male-dominated industries. In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), it informed the design of in-kind grants and personal initiative training; in Nigeria, it informed in the design of the SMEDevelopment and Growth Project, which supports entrepreneurship opportunities for youth and women, and a project aimed at developing innovative instruments to unlock commercial financing for women entrepreneurs. It has also informed programs supported by the Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi). Another example is from the AFR GIL (Gender Innovation Lab) that developed an innovative training program for entrepreneurs that has been expanded to nine countries: Ethiopia,Madagascar, Mauritania, Jamaica, and Nicaragua. Previously piloted in Togo,this personal initiative training focuses on future-oriented, persistent behaviour and developing an entrepreneurial mindset. An adaptation of the program is also being tested for the agriculture sector in Mozambique.
Closing Gender Gaps in Ownership and Control over Assets The UFGE private sector window enables the Bank and IFC to work with financial technology providers and financial institutions in client countries, to develop 'game-changing' solutions to enable women to have better access to finance by piloting and evaluating technology solutions to improve women's access to and use of financial services, while helping banks see women as a key market segment.
Regarding financial services, a joint IFC and Bangladesh Bank effort made the business case for electronic wage payments and helped secure buy-in from the mobile financial services (MFS) sector: between 2016 and 2018, more than 70,000 female garment workers opened mobile financial accounts. In FY19, this success helped convince the industry organization Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association (BGMEA) and international retail brands to advance the adoption of digital wage payments across the sector. The UFGE points to that market studies can be effective in convincing bank CEOs or their senior management teams of the business case of targeting women-owned SMEs. Only three percent of Cambodia's women entrepreneurs have access to formal credit, despite demand estimated at $4.2 billion. A study conducted in FY18 revealed that 61 percent of all businesses in Cambodia are owned by women, and that 90 percent of small and medium enterprises owned by women are profitable. This study helped encourage four Cambodian Banks to extend credit to thousands of women-owned SMEs (WSMEs), and collectively, the institutions now have 6,418 loans outstanding to WSMEs, to the value of over $340 million. A similar study was conducted in Vietnam and has informed the design of multi-year supply-chain financing programs in Indonesia and Vietnam to better support WSMEs.
Enhancing Womens Voice and Agency and Engaging Men and Boys The UFGE states that barriers to the full economic and social participation of women include gender-based violence (GBV), the prevalence of social norms that limit their opportunities, and the comparative shortage of women in leadership positions. Solutions will require a whole-society approach and particularly, the engagement of men and boys. UFGE grants are testing scalable approaches to changing social norms, including those that underpin the persistence of early marriage or the preference for boy children in some countries.
Under the area of GBV, the 2019 report, Respectful Workplaces: Exploring the Costs of Bullying and Sexual Harassment to Businesses in Myanmar, was produced by IFCs Gender Secretariat in partnership with the DaNa Facility and offers business leaders the opportunity to understand the prevalence and cost of bullying and harassment in the agribusiness, finance, retail and tourism sectors. It provides a set of practical recommendations, targeting business leaders, human resource managers, employees and other parties interested in creating workplaces that are safe and free from bullying and sexual harassment. Following the report, Myanmar companies have requested a Respectful Workplaces Masterclass, and IFC is exploring an opportunity to deliver this via its Investing in Women initiative. The Department of Social Welfare has requested a briefing on there search findings to inform their policy and practice. Outside Myanmar, clients such as STANBIC (Kenya), Ramatex (Vietnam), and Nepal Water and Energy Development Company Private Limited, have requested Respectful Workplace advisory services.Other examples include one on child marriage, a pilot conducted in partnership with the Ministry of Education in Bangladesh targeted the factors that influence the decision-making process of parents in an effort to prevent child marriage. The Ministry has confirmed that it would like to expand the program. Under the area of leadership, in FY19, a partnership between The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) and the IFC Corporate Governance Program in East Asia and the Pacific (EAP) studied the effects of gender diversity on the boards of companies in six ASEAN countries. The study showed that for gender diversity to have a significant impact on company performance and behavior, a critical mass of women must be in business leadership positions.
How evidence from UFGE research has informed World Bank Group
Sida, as well as other donors, has explicitly urged the UFGE to include more examples of how the knowledge emerging from UFGE's work is taken up within the WBG. One example in the 2019 report of how evidence from UFGE research has informed World Bank Group instruments and policy dialogue can be found in the Systematic Country Diagnostics (SCD), one of the Banks many tools to support client countries that help to influence policy dialogue on goals related to inclusive economic growth. To date, SCDs in 24 countries have cited findings from UFGE-supported analytical work.
